title: 'Low-carbon future' will arrive in a decade: APRA exec
text:
"People are going to get caught on that [but] there are going to be organisations that also make an enormous amount of return on those transitions, as has been the case with every structural change that has occurred within the economy."

Mr Summerhayes called for more honest conversations about how to deal with the "existential nature" of climate change and Australia's contribution to warming.

Conversations had thus far been polite but probably needed to be more forthright, he told the gathering of institutional investors.

"I would advocate that we have more forthright, open conversations but we take people with us on that journey because the transition to a low-carbon future will have impacts that will not be equal across the economy."

Mr Summerhayes was responding to a question about how regulators like APRA plan to deal with the fact that Australian commodity exports are making the climate problem worse.

"Some parts of the economy will be much harder hit than others and as a society we need to think about how we look after those sections of society that will be very adversely affected so that the majority of society can transition to the low-carbon future."

Earlier this year, APRA surveyed 38 large banks, insurers and superannuation funds about their responses to climate change risk.

A third of respondents cited climate change as a material risk to their business, with reputational damage, flooding, regulatory changes and cyclones the top concerns.

Mr Summerhayes said APRA had since been conducting "deep dives" with each of the 38 organisations and would release a thematic review.
description: One of the nation's most senior regulators says the transition to low-carbon energy will happen more quickly than anticipated - probably by 2030.
